title: 10 Key definitions
summary: Glendenning provides foundational definitions of core educational concepts. Learner: a person initiating change in their life, carrying three pieces of "luggage" (inherent conditions, prior learning, future aspirations), filling diverse life roles (individual, family member, student, citizen, consumer, producer). Learning: multidimensional experience with formative effects on thoughts, feelings, and actions, occurring anywhere/anytime. Education: accumulated experiences with measurable effects on person's development. Education System: community services supporting people's development. Teaching: arranging experiences creating changes in others' knowledge, beliefs, and capabilities. These definitions distinguish education from schooling and position learners as active agents with complex backgrounds and multiple life roles, reflecting his learner-centered philosophy.
content_preview:
About education

Glendenning 

KEY DEFINITIONS

Doc 5

Education in Canada is a provincial responsibility; the role of a Province is to encourage, support and regulate education services; in the case of PEI. Although ducation services are not separately identified they appear to be mainly delivered through schools, college. universities and private schools. Although the system allows for independent study the writer is unsure at the moment just how that works. Like most Provinces, PEI appears to be serviced by a school system rather than an education system. 

While it is likely that a taxonomy of common education terms used in PEI exists, the writer did not come across one; the following reflects the writer’s views on key education concepts:

  
Learner – a person who, for whatever reason, needs, wants or is trying to bring about change in his/her life – trying to change an acritude, gain new knowledge, or add skills. But learners are neither empty jars nor blank slates; each learner carries three pieces of luggage to every new learning situation (1) certain physical, mental and emotional conditions with which a learner is born, (b) prior learning resulting from home circumstances, formal study, travel, state of health, personal interests, culture in which learner operates and (3) aspirations and imagined future including where one will live, the work one will do and the lifestyle one will have, nature of the family, quality of life, etc. . Learners have different interests, experiences, capabilities and needs. Learners also fill a variety of life roles, that of an individual, family member, student, citizen, consumer and producer
  
Learning- a process of engaging in experiences that have a formative effect on the way we think, feel and act. Learning is multidimensional; it can happen any place and any time, when one is alone as well as when people gather together, it may be satisfied by something as simple as a bit of information or as complex as understanding th...

title: 100 -Beliefs, core  PrinciolesOverhaulI
summary: A working draft addressing the absence of foundational belief statements in PEI's education system. Don advocates for clear, written core beliefs to guide organizational decision-making, comparing the need to Holland College's early development with "a dozen or so foundational statements." He critiques the 1989 provincial philosophy of education as outdated and vague, and proposes involving MLAs rather than educators in developing a replacement. Includes extensive notes on systemic problems and recommendations.
content_preview:
Editor







Core Beliefs

Education, in fact every organization, needs a set of core beliefs to guide decision-making, and the list should be written and widely quoted.  Such a document can take many forms – a philosophy, mission, mandate or guiding principles,  A properly crafted statement becomes a reference statement for the organization, improves communication, increases consistency, supports decentralization, is a development tool,  assures the public that the organization is well run – a set of beliefs is a basic document from which all decisions flow.  

Such a document may well exist but I have not been able to find it.  Yes, I know there is a ”philosophy of education” that applies to public schooling, but it is out of date and conveniently fuzzy; mandate letters tend to deal with priorities not foundational beliefs, as do Ministerial Directives.  I browsed a number of school websites as well as those of the University and Holland College. None of my searches revealed the kind of document that  I feel is necessary. It should be brief, a page or two at most; Holland College, based its early development a dozen or so foundational statements.

While the process requires the input of educators, I’m not sure that it should be led by an educator; I view education as a service to Islanders, this document is a public stafement as to the principles on which the system will be built.  Could the committee be com[psed of MLA”s?










 







I am not suggesting a Newfoundland or Nova Scotia style study; we should prepare the plan ourselves with outside help if needed.   



















For example, I happen to believe that learning is a personal matter, learners bring widely different levels of pitot learning to each learning activity and some learners learn more quickly than others. All of this conflicts with the pattern of grading, group movement through various grades and timed learning periods.  













Introductory pages of the various program outl...

title: 100-Change
summary: An August 2020 newsletter discussing transformative policy shifts in Australia and Ontario toward outcomes-based education funding and post-school success tracking. Don notes Australia's focus on employment/unemployment status five years post-graduation and its emphasis on phonics, attendance, and Aboriginal education. Identifies three key issues: well-defined goals, inter-provider communication, and quality focus. Cautions against a "standards race" mentality and emphasizes the need for holistic success measures.

title: 100 Math
summary: A comprehensive May 2020 discussion paper prepared by Education 20/20 Inc. addressing numeracy education on PEI. Based on the 2013 Community Foundation PEI survey and six public discussions, the paper defines math and numeracy, reviews international evidence, identifies systemic fragmentation, and proposes 16+ recommendations including competency-based frameworks, independent rating scales, and learner profiles. Demonstrates Don's systematic approach to policy research combining empirical evidence, stakeholder input, and organizational reform principles.
content_preview:
MATH FOR EVERYDAY LIVING

   D 100  A Discussion Paper                   						        May 2020

____________________________________________________________________________




In late 2013, The Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island (CFPEI) undertook a survey of over 200 Island youth to identify issues that directly affected them; the report, Taking the Pulse of Island Youth, available on the Foundation’s website at www.cfpei.ca, provides a snapshot of the findings.  Bright spots include a positive sense of community, emerging entrepreneurial spirit, volunteerism and new postsecondary offerings. The main concerns include a lack of jobs, surviving on low-paying jobs, educational deficiencies and drug and alcohol addictions.  On the subject of education and learning, the study reports a high rate of completion of high school and postsecondary education, a high level of inclusivity and relatively affordable tuition costs; young people also expressed concerns about their readiness for the next stage of life including: 




“preparedness gaps with regard to readiness for

postsecondary study and the workplace” – Vital Signs, CFPEI, 2013




Following the publication of the CFPEI Report, Education 20/20 organized six public discussions for the purpose of informing the community about the report and its findings, learning more about youth issues in our communities, exploring issues of education and learning, and to identify actions to be taken to close gaps.  Discussions were lively and wide ranging and carried on well after formal sessions ended.   Education 20/20 retained an interest in the subject and continued its exploration through informal discussion with educators, employers, students and the community at large. 




EDUCATION

Consistent decision making requires a set of basic beliefs about learners and learning; this paper is based on the view that:

  
Learning is an individual matter
  
Although groups do not learn, individuals may learn in a group sett...

title: 100 OverhaulI
summary: A working draft essay restating Don's core critique: PEI's education system is narrowly focused on school delivery, lacks direction, and prevents necessary systemic change. He defines education broadly as "any experience that has a formative effect on the way a person thinks, feels or acts" and calls for government to "encourage, support and regulate" rather than directly deliver. Proposes adopting competency-based learning, dynamic rating scales, and democratic school governance. Includes detailed outline of current problems, responsibility gaps, and OECD recommendations.
content_preview:
D-100

Editor

Time for an overhaul

Education services on PEI need an overhaul; they are narrowly focused, cognitively based, bureaucratic, lack accountability and focus on program delivery rather than on learner development – they also lack a self-correcting mechanism.  I do not, we cannot, blame the current government, the previous government or any single government that went before for the current status; Government has a responsibility however, for instituting corrective measures.  

There is a growing gap between education services needed and education services provided. 

Islanders want our students to be literate and numerate, to become independent learners, to take care of themselves and learn how to work and play together. Education’s business is to help Islanders gain new and better skills, knowledge, attitudes and values.  We wonder if  our students would benefit from holistic rating scales, competency based learning, self- paced programs and schools operating on democratic principles.  W know that money is needed for buses. buildings, salaries and technology but tell us how spending those dollars improves education. The conversation is bogged down on matters of administrivia (school upgrading, credits, grades, noon meals, technology, etc.) at the expense of changes that  help Islanders gain knowledge, skills, attitudes and values needed to help them to thrive in later life.

It is the writer’s view that much of the needed change is blocked by an outdated  system; we’ve embedded education in a body that can give it neither direction, freedom nor support needed to accomplish the task at hand.  Government not only needs to change a number of existing policies and practices but also needs to allow, nay encourage,  change to happen.  

It’s  time for a public conversation about education on PEI. then we need a plan.  PEI has 150,000 citizens; all are potential users of educational services. Their need s, interests and capabilities are many and varied, but p...

title: 102-5 Role of Gov
summary: The most developed version of the government role discussion, framing education as a service system requiring explicit resource allocation decisions. Don references Education 20/20's consultation with youth about needed educational support (information, analysis, feedback, instruction, counseling, coaching). Advocates for healthcare-style service definitions stating what government will fund. Proposes functional rather than school-based organization and questions current delivery assumptions. References OECD (autonomy), Montreal Economic Institute (accountability), UNESCO (access), and UNICEF (relevance) as reform guides.
content_preview:
Editor

Dear
Sir	

Re-setting
direction


An
education system is an array of programs and services put in place by
a community
to encourage and support the education of its citizens; support is
usually  focused on  (1) helping individual citizens gain skills,
knowledge, attitudes and values that help them thrive in the years
ahead and (2) providing human resources needed to maintain the
community as a place people want to live.  From my perspective, the
current Department has 150,000 Islanders potentially looking or help.
 


If
we accept the above, we are then faced with the question as to what
help is needed.  Some time ago, Education 20/20 convened a group of
young people and asked them that question; they responded with.  a
long list of ideas, chief among them being assistance with gathering
information, analyzing experiences, obtaining feedback, obtaining
instruction, evaluating selves, coaching others, practicing what is

was needed, not surprisingly, students followed quite different
paths. Restated, the student list above is similar to typical
education services such as governance, leadership.  funding,
regulation, information, counselling, instruction, quality assurance,
learning products and human resources.   Communities, employers,
postsecondary institutions would likely be equally happy to respond
to questions about their needs as well.

What
kind and how much “educational support” should taxpayers pay for?
 The Canada Health Plan, I am told, has an agreed upon list of health

approach.  It would be an  interesting exercise and one that would

title: 102 Role of Gov
summary: A comprehensive working draft defining government's education role and PEI's structural shortcomings. Don articulates that government should encourage, support, and regulate rather than directly provide education. Notes a widening gap between community needs and services offered. References Donald Savoie's critique of government service delivery, OECD findings on school autonomy, and the Montreal Economic Institute's accountability recommendations. Criticizes education's narrow focus on school-based instruction and proposes function-based organization with independent oversight.
content_preview:
Not sure what government id trying to do

Role of government in education	103

Time for an overhaul of education

Communities are of the view that education is important; in response, government has put in place an education system, an array of programs and services to encourage and support the education of its citizens .Governments do so for two reasons; (1) to support the education of its citizens and (2) because they need skilled people to ensure the viability of the commniity in which they live.   Provincial support typically comes in the form of funding, regulation, information,  counselling, instruction, quality assurance, education products. 

Communities suffer, however, because education is narrowly defined (using education and schooling interchangeably) , by the labelling of  the portfolios as “Education and lifelong Learning” or,  as the case of the  former Government, “Education and Early Childhood Development”   Government fails to recognize that education already  encompasses both. 

In addition, Government has a patchy record when it comes to responding to community needs,  part time and continuing education, services to small  communities.I  ’ve reported before on he interest of Souris residents in lifelong learning, in practical and hands on training and in online courses. Nor do they address the issue of quality




Readers may remember










 Encouragement is quite straight forward and could be as simple as providing information.  




Then we need some overarching statements g principle such as:

  
PEI will underwrite the cost of instruction in literacy up to level three (whatever that is)
  
Instructional services in literacy will be provided through public schools
  
Te fundamental responsibility for education rests with the family
  
Funding for post secondary education will be provided through grants to families

title: 11 Elections
summary: Policy governing Director election and terms. Directors are elected at annual meetings for three-year terms with re-election eligibility, serve no more than two consecutive uninterrupted terms, and continue until the next annual meeting following term expiration. The Board appoints interim directors for vacancies with ratification at subsequent annual meetings. This structure balances leadership continuity with democratic renewal.

title: 111 A- What's An A
summary: A thoughtful essay questioning what an "A" grade actually means and advocating for clear definitions of academic achievement standards. Don compares school grading systems to medical evaluation, arguing that educators should be able to define performance standards just as doctors understand health metrics. He provides examples of "A" performance in various skills and argues for accountability in using grades.
content_preview:
WHAT’’S AN “A”?







An A is a high mark; the only better one would be AA, AAA, or even AAAA but they are not awarded.  The top students in school, college or university are the A students.  They weren’t born A students; or if they were, they were not labeled as such.  While parents may think they have a smart, no parent I know would refer to their child an A, B or C child.  It is only after children start school that they become known as A students; the school likes labels, I guess.  The school system often applies other labels as well, or instead, such as B, C, D or F,  They may also give students a G.P.A. or even a figure ranging from zero to one hundred 




A student may earn an A on a single assignment, all assignments, on projects or an exam; that student got an A on the course.  A student who earns an A on all subjects is known as a “straight A” student.  Many students get a mixture of A’s, B’s, C’s, D’s, and even F’s or their equivalent.   Such students are labeled with different letters.  Sometimes schools takes the numbers for each child on each subject at the end of the years to determine general school; the logic of averaging marks on math, social studies, science and phys ed continues to elude me/   




The health system also uses numbers when determining the state of a person’s health.  During a recent visit, my doctor quoted such figures as 170 pounds, 120 over 70 blood pressure, pulse of 72, a PSA of 4 and so on.  None of these numbers required judgment; all were based on tests.  With figures in hand, and without averaging my test results, he proceeded with judgments about my current state of health and I am happy to report that there were no major changes - either improvements or deteriorations.   I am intrigued by the differences between the ways the two systems deals with their information about their clients.  A doctor uses the numbers to determine the state of a person’s health (no averaging of tests from different specialties); a teacher as...

title: 12 Types of Funds
summary: Comprehensive policy describing nine fund types available to donors through CFPEI: Un-restricted funds giving foundation full discretion; Restricted funds for named agencies; Advised funds where donors suggest grants; Interest funds limited to donor-identified areas; Scholarships/Bursaries; Managed funds for other charities; Agency funds restricted to specified organizations; Memorial funds; Flow-through funds; and Project funds. This taxonomy reflects the foundation's sophisticated approach to accommodating diverse donor intentions while maintaining administrative clarity.
content_preview:
Date	

THE COMMUNITY FOUNDATION OF PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND 







Category	   :					Policy No:

Approval Date   :					Effective date:

Last Amendment:

Board Approval:				

______________________________________________________________________________




Subject:	Types of Funds




The community foundation of Prince Edward island offers the following types of Funnds as for vehicles for Donors:




Un-restricted – wherein the Founndation has full authority to distribute funds to meet any social, cultural, educational, religious and/or human services need in Prince Edwardm Island




Restricted- whereby the donor restricts the payment at the time of the gift to a named charitable agency or specific project.  The foundation agrees to respect the donor’s wishes as long as the agency or project continues to serve the public interest.




Advised – under which a donor retains the right to advise the foundation regarding grants and the foundation retains the right to accwept or ignore the advice.




Interest – funds which limit the discretion of the foundation to making grants to areas of interest identified by the donor.




Scholarships and Bursaries – whereby the donor identifies target populations which may include institutions, courses of study, geographic areas, financial need or some other pertinent criteria.




Managed – funds are owned by another charitable organization but are placed with the foundation for the purpose of investment  and may be withdrawn from the foundation with reasonable notice. 




Agency – are owned by the foundation but grants may only be paid to the agency named in the agreement.




Memorial – are the result of donations in memory of a friend, colleague or relative, either living or deceased, and may be either credited towards an endowment or be flowed through




Flow-through – funds aregiven to the foundation with the provision that they be forwarded to one or more donees and for which the foundation may charge an administration  fee.

PREFACE











The
author grew up in the community of Black River and in St. Paul’s
Presbyterian Church.  St. Paul’s was an integral part of our family
life; my mother and father were among the founders.  This paper is an
informal and brief record of St. Paul’s Church, in the context of
more than two centuries of Presbyterianism along the south shore of
the Miramichi River in New Brunswick, Canada.  







Much of
the information was gathered during brief visits to the Miramichi;
longer visits would have provided greater access to church records,
newspapers of the day and interviews with church members.  While care
was taken in gathering information, transcription errors are
possible.  While the revision includes all of the original material,
it has also allowed me to add some additional information on Church
Union of 1925, add photos and make some minor changes in the text and
appendices.

title: 2015-2 Award Description En@2014-11-09T04;56;40
summary: Official description of Education 20/20 Inc.'s Excellence in Education Award (2015), established with Island family funding to recognize schools demonstrating high engagement. Award emphasizes family-school-community partnerships, citing research showing parental involvement improves student achievement and school morale. Five engagement areas evaluated: student-to-student, student-to-teacher, student-to-instruction, school-community partnerships, and parent involvement in education.
content_preview:
Excellence
in Education Award - 2015






BACKGROUND






Our
future as individuals and as communities depends to a large degree on
the quality of our education.  Gaining a quality education,
therefore, should be a major focus of every citizen, providing a
quality education should be the focus of governments, and providing a
quality education the objective of every teacher and school.  An
award is for having done something done rather than a grant to do
something.  







Thanks to the
generosity of an Island family, Education 20/20 Inc. has established
an awards program as a mechanism to call attention by the public to
important characteristics of effective schools and to provide some
recognition to schools for their efforts to implement them.  The
focus of the award is on engagement for, as the National Parent
Teacher Association points out that “when families, schools, and
communities work together student achievement improves, teacher
morale rises and communication increases”. Study after study show
the dramatic impact parental involvement makes to a child's success
in school. In fact, engaging families in their children’s education
improves school achievement, attendance, behaviour and graduation
rates.  The focus will be on the daily operation of the school and on
those items over which the school has substantial control.  
 







ELEMENTS OF
ENGAGEMENT

Education is
interested in a broad engagement across the institution including:

	


	Student engagement with peers showing based on respect,
	cultural competency, caring, courtesy, tact, honour, cooperation and
	collaboration. 
	










	


	Learning environment should be welcoming  and one that is
	safe and comfortable physically and emotionally, based on the
	assumptions of respect, cultural competency, trust, care, optimism
	and intentionality.  School encourages integration of learning
	across courses and invites students to discuss “big
	questions” that matter beyond the classroom.    Teacher enc...

title: 2015-7 Selection Process@2014-11-01T18;19;31
summary: Detailed selection process for Education 20/20's Engagement Award (2014-15). Committee members review nomination packages using scoring grids, prepare comments, identify top candidates by numerical scoring, meet under board-member chairmanship to ensure inclusive discussion, decide by consensus or executive override, and recommend recipient to Board for final approval. Emphasizes transparent, collaborative decision-making.
content_preview:
Education 20/20 Selection Process for the “Engagement Award”

EDUCATION 20/20 INC.

Excellence in Education

Awards Program – 2014-15




	

1. Selection Committee members receive the completed nomination packages.  A member of the Selection Committee notifies the nominees and asks if they wish their name to stand.  Following these confirmations, the list of nominees and respective packages are dispersed to members of the Selection Committee.   Members review nominations and prepare comments for discussion at the selection committee meeting. Each committee member should come to the meeting prepared with a list of who they feel are the two strongest candidates for the award.  Selection of the strongest will be made based on a numerical scoring and comments. (See attached grid.)

	




2. The selection committee meeting will be chaired by a board member of Education 20/20 Association. The purpose of the chair is to ensure all committee members have opportunity to bring forward their ideas and that no one person dominates the decision making process.

	




3. Decisions will be made by consensus. In the event that the committee is unable to reach consensus, the final decision will be made by the Education 20/20 executive member on the selection committee.

	




4. The committee will propose one potential recipient to the Education 20/20 Board of Directors, for the Board’s final decision, with documentation provided.

title: 28 Pumpkin Preserves
summary: Traditional pumpkin preserves recipe yielding 4 pints, featuring cubed pumpkin, sugar, lemon, and cloves. Recipe includes detailed step-by-step instructions for preparation, cooking, and preservation in sterile jars. Source appears to be food.com, suggesting Carol's use of online resources to supplement or verify traditional recipes in her collection.
content_preview:
Pumpkin Preserves




Ingredients: 



Yield: 4 pints 



Units: US | Metric 



8 cups cubed peeled pumpkin (1/2 inch cubes) 

4 cups granulated sugar 

1 lemon 

5 whole cloves 



Directions: 



1 Layer pumpkin with sugar in a large bowl. 

2 Cover and let stand overnight, stirring once or twice. 

3 Next day, drain juice off of pumpkin into saucepan. 

4 Bring to a boil and boil for 10 minutes. 

5 Add pumpkin pieces, grated rind and chopped pulp of the lemon. 

6 Add cloves (tied in a cheesecloth bag). 

7 Cook on a slow boil for 40 minutes, or until pumpkin is clear and the mixture 

   sheets from a spoon. 

8 Remove the cloves and pour into hot sterile jars. 

9 Seal. 



Read more at: http://www.food.com/recipe/pumpkin-preserves-85315?oc=linkback

title: 4 Yard
summary: Comprehensive guide to cottage yard maintenance documenting Don's knowledge of property upkeep. Documents shared stair management with Galloways (treated lumber, removable railing attachment with lag screws, annual repositioning due to erosion). Describes shed maintenance (set on blocks, front corner sag issues, staining every 3-5 years). Provides detailed operating instructions for three mowers: old rototiller (engine beyond repair), Lawnboy (mixed gas), and John Deere (purchased 2008, requires regular maintenance and grease checks). Extensive practical knowledge compiled by Don reflecting decades of property stewardship and attention to detail.

Garden

Garden soil is quite rich but may blow off.

Jointly owned and managed with Galloway’s

Stairs made of treated lumber and do not require staining

The railing is permanently attached to the stairs, however, an additional piece is needed at the top as one approaches the stairs; this piece is added after stairs are put down and removed before stairs are pulled up. We fasten the removable piece with lag screws so that it will be easy to attach and remove annually.  

Because of erosion, a bit of adjusting is required each ear especially at the top of the stairs.  Make sure that the approach is level so that a person will not catch a toe and fall down the stairs...

title: 40 2016-05-26 - no. 40 - External Criteria
summary: English-language version of newsletter no. 40 (dated May 25, 2016) on criterion-referenced testing. Includes identical coverage of Grace Christian School's Excellence in Education Award with Don Glendenning as President of Education 20/20. Shows his editorial leadership and continued involvement in PEI educational policy discussions post-retirement from Holland College.
content_preview:
Open
Education					
    




40										             May 25, 2016








The school
of life never stops teaching. – Steven Aitcheson








	Criterion-referenced
	testing
	

	


	
	

	Criterion-referenced
	testing is an approach to assessment in which a student’s
	performance is compared to a predefined set of criteria or standards
	and not with the work of other test takers.  Criterion-referenced
	testing is used to determine whether a person has reached a
	predetermined level of achievement and results are usually reported
	in terms of pass or fail, a driver’s test or an apprentice exam
	are good examples; all who take the exam may pass or all may fail.
	

	


	
	

	The
	goal with these tests is to determine the level that a candidate has
	achieved on a certain skill or set of skills and to use it as a
	basis for making decisions about job entry, certification, or
	licensure.  The key to criterion-referenced testing is
	clearly-stated outcomes, a set of clearly-defined levels, an
	external benchmark and the consistent application of the assessment
	process.
	

	The
	assessment process must be transparent and the grades derived should
	be defined in terms a student understands – students should be
	able to trace their grades to the specifics of their performance on
	the tasks that were set. In fact, it is well understood that the
	discussion between teacher and learner about the grade assigned is
	an important part of the learning experience; criterion-referenced
	testing provides a framework for students and teachers to fully
	engage in the learning process. 
	
	

	Separating
	the teaching and grading process increases consistency and minimizes
	bias.
	

	


	
	

	


	
	

	


	
	

	


	
	

	


	
	

	Excellence
	in Education Award
	

	


	
	

	

	
From
	left to right: Katherine McQuaid, Maureen Kerr, Jason Biech and Don
	Glendenning
	

	


	
	

	


	
	
Grace
	Christian School was named this year’s winner of the Excellence in
	Education Award.  The award is prese...

title: 41 2016-06-25 - no. 41 - Criterion-Referenced (FR)
summary: French-language newsletter no. 41 (June 25, 2016) edited by Don Glendenning featuring an article on criterion-referenced testing and a section on the Digital Pedagogy Lab Institute (#DigPed) hosted by UPEI's Faculty of Education July 13-15, 2016. Includes photo of Glendenning thanking Roger Birt, President of R. Birt and Associates, for financial support of Education 20/20 Inc. Reflects his continued leadership in PEI educational innovation and community partnerships.
content_preview:
Pédagogie
ouverte					
    




41										             25 juin 2016







C’est
la nature de la connaissance que personne ne peut tout savoir
(traduction libre) – auteur inconnu








	Test
	axé sur des critères
	

	Le
	test axé sur des critères est une approche selon laquelle
	l'évaluation de la performance d'un élève est comparée à un
	ensemble prédéfini de critères ou de normes et non pas avec le
	travail des autres personnes testées. Le test axé sur des critères
	est utilisé afin de déterminer si une personne a atteint un degré
	d’apprentissage prédéterminé et les résultats sont
	généralement présentés en termes de succès ou d'échec, le test
	de conduite ou l’examen d'apprenti en sont des exemples; tous ceux
	qui prennent l'examen peuvent réussir ou ils peuvent échouer.
	

	Le
	but de ces tests est de déterminer si un candidat a atteint une
	certaine habileté ou un ensemble de compétences et fournira le
	fondement pour prendre des décisions en matière d’embauche, de
	certification ou d'autorisation d'exercer. La clé du test axé sur
	des critères est des résultats clairement énoncés, une série de
	niveaux clairement définis, une référence externe et
	l'application uniforme du processus d'évaluation.
	

	Le
	processus d'évaluation doit être transparent et les notes qui en
	sont dérivées doivent être définies de sorte que l’étudiant
	puisse bien les comprendre – les élèves devraient être en
	mesure de retracer leurs notes aux spécificités de leur

title: 43 2016-08-18 - no. 43 - Other Perspective (FR)

title: 49 2017-02-20 - no 49 - Beliefs
summary: English-language newsletter no. 49 (February 20, 2017) edited by Don Glendenning on personal beliefs about education. Opens with John Dewey quote and shares Glendenning's core educational beliefs: all people can learn but may need varying time; learning is individual; early childhood education (first six years) is most critical; education's purpose is lifelong skill development; individuals bear responsibility for their own education; community future depends on citizen education; and government's role includes encouraging education, ensuring equity, and maintaining community skill pools. Congratulates Erin Johnston, Principal of Prince Street Elementary School (2015 Excellence Award winner), as one of Canada's outstanding principals. Highly valuable for understanding Glendenning's educational philosophy post-Holland College.
content_preview:
Open
	Education                           
	

	

	No. 49									    	                   	February
	20, 2017
	

	


	
	

	Less
	bureaucracy, more democracy – Andy Hargreaves




	


	



	BELIEFS
	



	
	
John
	Dewey once said that if he could only know one thing about a person,
	he’d want to know what the person believes; interestingly,
	however, the matter of beliefs seldom arises in my conversations
	with educators. 
	
	



	
	
As
	a place to start, let me share some of my personal beliefs:
	
		


		All
		people can learn but some may need more time than others.
		


		Learning
		is an individual matter but may occur in a group setting.
		


		The
		most important part of one’s education is the part that occurs in
		the first six years of life.
		


		The
		purpose of education is to help a person gain attitudes, skills and
		use of knowledge for the remainder of their journey through life.
		


		The
		responsibility for one’s education rests with one’s self.
		


		Our
		future as a community depends, in a large measure, on the nature
		and level of education of our citizens. 
		
		


		The
		role of a Provincial Government is (1) to encourage education among
		its citizens, (2) to ensure equity in its support and (3) to
		maintain a pool of skills needed to ensure the future of the
		community in which we live.
		


		An
		education system should be designed to deliver educational services
		to the extent possible, as and when needed.
	
	



	
	
“Are
	beliefs cast in stone?” The answer is “no”; are they likely to
	change tomorrow? The answer is also “no”. Beliefs change as we
	learn new things; changes usually result in a changed word or two. 
	Eventually, but not often, changes may become an entirely new
	belief.  Having a set of beliefs, I find it to be very useful when
	it comes to ease and consistency of decision making. 
	
	

	POT
	POURRI

title: 5 Components of an Education System@2015-12-28T10;09;43
summary: A duplicate or updated version of the education system components framework, maintaining the same seven-part structure covering information services, formal institutions, community organizations, certification, governance, resources, and qualified staff essential to comprehensive education delivery.
content_preview:
Abt/A




Components of an Education system




  
Information, counselling and advice for people who make decisions about their own or a family member’s education. 


  
Institutions, places with desks and chairs, for people who want or need formal instruction


  
Community based organizations such as libraries, youth organizations, access centres, employer training, service clubs, NGO’s and Itinerant teachers that provide instruction, information, tutoring, experience in non-formal education
  
Certification and qualification service for individuals and organizations that want or need their levels of performance.
  
Governance structure to provide leadership, planning, research, coordination and monitoring. 
  
Resource materials such as textbooks, technological applications, devices and supplies. 
  
Qualified staff –to ensure that the human resources are available to provide services required.

title: 500 WHAT an A
summary: Don questions what "A" grades actually signify, noting schools apply such labels despite no evidence they meaningfully describe student capability. He contrasts educational grading with medical assessment: doctors use specific measurements (weight, blood pressure, PSA levels) without averaging across categories to inform clinical judgment, while teachers average unrelated subjects' grades. Don sought written explanations of what constitutes an "A" from schools with minimal success, finding transcripts unhelpful. He argues an "A" should clearly define performance—does it mean writing clearly, having superior vocabulary, speaking logically? If so, say so; if not, what does it mean? He provides examples: a plumber who solves problems independently, a writer using creative expression with proper grammar, a technician understanding deep processes. People deserve to know what grade labels mean, and employers need such clarity for hiring decisions.
content_preview:
WHAT’’S AN A?







An “A” is a high mark; the only better one would be A+, AA, AAA, or even AAAA. The top students in school, college or university are the “A” students.  People weren’t born “A” students; or if they were, they were not labeled as such.  While parents may think they have a smart child, no parent I know would refer to their child an A, B or C child.  It is only after children start school that they become so classified; schools like labels, I guess.  The school system often applies other labels as well, or instead of, letters; they may also give students a GPA. Number or even a figure ranging from zero to one hundred. 




A student may earn an A on a single assignment, all assignments, on projects or an exam or even a subject studied for a whole year.  A student who earns an A on all subjects is known as a “straight A” student.  Many students get a mixture of A’s, B’s, C’s, D’s, and even F’s.  Schools often average student's marks for a year although the logic of averaging marks on such diverse subjects as math, social studies, science and physical education continues to elude me.  




The health system also uses numbers when determining the state of a person’s health.  During a recent visit, my doctor quoted such figures as 170 pounds, 120 over 70 blood pressure, pulse of 72 and figures for PSA, cholesterol, etc.  None of these numbers required judgment; all were based on tests.  With figures in hand, and without averaging my test results, my doctor proceeded with judgments about my current state of health; I am happy to report that there were no major changes - either improvements or deteriorations.   




I am intrigued by the differences in the ways the two systems deals with their information about the individuals they serve.  A doctor uses the numbers to determine the state of a person’s health (no averaging of tests from different specialties); a teacher assigns numbers to announce the level of one’s knowledge of a field.




I made some en...

title: 6 Backgrounf paper
summary: Comprehensive background research paper establishing the theoretical foundation for Don's achievement levels initiative. References public concern about educational standards, citing No Child Left Behind, labour mobility, and technology's impact on instruction. Don analyzes successful alternative models including apprenticeship programs, the Canadian Language authority, International Baccalaureate, and Canadian Conservatory of Music. He critiques current PEI practice for lacking externally referenced criteria and maintaining conflicts between teaching and grading functions. The document examines assessment versus evaluation (using Robert Paul Wolf's 1969 framework), identifies best practices internationally, and articulates characteristics of needed qualification authorities—emphasizing independence, laddering, and reduced bias.

title: 70 Recipe for math
summary: Essay reflecting on Don's farming childhood and cooking experience to argue for increased emphasis on basic math skills for Island students. Published in Open Education newsletter (No. 70, November 2018). Includes mention of Education 20/20 Souris area survey. Demonstrates Don's approach to education reform through practical analogy.
content_preview:
Open
	Education                           
	

	

	No. 70							   			November 20, 2018
	
Ontarians
	don’t trust government to improve quality of postsecondary
	education-
	
Globe
	& Mail



	


	
	

	A
	RECIPE FOR MATH
	

	I’m
	a passable cook; the year I graduated from high school, my mother
	had a leg infection and was not very mobile.  As the youngest in the
	family, I became the “cookee” while my older brothers ran the
	farm.  Under mother’s direction, I learned to make tea, cook
	vegetables, make stew, biscuits and gingerbread, and to do it all on
	a wood stove.  All my siblings survived.   
	
	

	


	
	

	It
	was a fairly sharp learning curve; the market for my product was
	secure. Even though I knew new the market and recognized the
	elements, vegetables, condiments and utensils. It was the pinch of
	salt, simmer ‘til brown and let the dough rise that I lacked.  The
	key to improvement was a whole lot of practise of basic skills in a
	real life setting several times each day.  I’m wondering if the
	same doesn’t apply to learning math as well.
	

	


	
	

	There’s
	hardly a day goes by, it seems, that I don’t encounter media
	stories about education, grade inflation and teacher preparation in
	Ontario, curriculum in Alberta, declining grades in the USA and
	concerns of Island employers. Improvements, at least those offered
	to the public, usually involves increasing the knowledge level. My
	summer cooking experience, however, suggests increasing each
	student’s experience and comfort level with basic applications
	comes first.
	

	


	
	

	I’m
	pleased to report that I still cook and have successfully added
	omelettes, fudge and pumpkin preserves to my skillset. Based on my
	cooking experience, I now recommend increased emphasis on every day
	math for all Island students.
	

	


	
	

	


	
	

	


	
	

	SOURIS
	STUDY
	
Education

	the Souris area of PEI.  The study included a review of current
	...

title: 97 Improving numeracy
summary: Don distinguishes between education as a service to learners versus education as a product focused on credentials. He argues that educational achievement should be demonstrated through practical competencies (writing, repairs, household management) rather than abstract credentials, and criticizes the prevalence of course numbers, credits, and grades in departmental communications. He advocates for educational reporting that reflects real-world competencies learners have developed, drawing implicit contrast with the current system's focus on administrative credentials and course structures rather than demonstrated capability.

title: A Wilmot-1
summary: Draft emails from Don to Louise and Jim Wilmot regarding the Souris Garden Club project. Don indicates strong support for the garden initiative, noting that he and Jeniene believe it merits promotion beyond Souris boundaries. He requests Sarah and Ilse prepare budget scenarios for three funding levels ($2,500, $3,500, $5,000) to support the project. Don mentions discovering matching fund opportunities that could expand project scope. The correspondence demonstrates Don's collaborative leadership style, his ability to identify funding mechanisms, and his strategic thinking about scaling successful community programs. The personal tone and optimistic outlook show his enthusiasm for educational innovation.
content_preview:
Draft Email to Wilmots

Just a a brief note to let you know that Jeniene and I met yesterday to discuss the Souris Garden Club.  We agree that it is a good project and deserves support?  In fact, we are of the view that the model should be promoted beyond the boundaries of Souris



We are asking Sarah and Ilse to provide bit more detail and to do provide for three levels of support, say$2500, $3,500 and $5,000; if this does not match your thinking, please advise.  We will work with Sarah and Ilse and be back in touch. 

Thanks to Jeniene, we've discovered the possibility of matching funds; if that were to happen, we probably could all that they have in mind plus more.

We’ll keep you posted; trust all is well

Regards

Don  



Draft Email to Ilse and Sarah

We are optimistic that some funds can be found to help move your project along.  To do so, we need a bit more information.  Would you provide a page or so, not too long, outlining what you would do in 2017  with $2,500, $3,500 and $5,000.  We think that the project may be of interest to other communities and, if you agree, would like you to consider an additional component, that of making a presentation about  your project elsewhere in PEI.



Feel free to share any drafts you prepare (copy to Jeniene); we are happy to work with you in developing your proposals.

Regards

Don

title: Backgroundl-6

title: Chores
summary: Don describes two categories of farm chores: watering cattle at noon during winter school breaks (requiring arduous trips to the frozen brook under Miller's Bridge, chipping ice for the cows to drink) and feeding orphan piglets using a recipe from his brother Walter's record book. These memories illustrate the rigorous daily labor of farm life and Don's childhood responsibilities, including school absences sanctioned by teachers for farm work.
content_preview:
Noon Chores

 Perhaps because we lived so close to the school, there were usually chores to be done when home for lunch.  One such chore was watering the cattle at noon hour in the winter.

Although we had a water pump in the house there was none in the barn, therefore, one had to either carry water by the pail from the house to the barn or take the cattle to the brook.  Not a problem in the summer but winter was another story.  The only open portion of the brook in the winter was directly under the Miller’s Bridge.  Even at that, the ice built up as a result of the rising and falling tide in the cold weather and had to be chipped with an axe so the cows could climb down to the water.

 

When Norm and moved to the Miramichi High school, it became my turn.  Usually, Mum wrote “an excuse” to the teacher so we could leave school about 11:00 o’clock or so to chip the ice, let out the cows, herd them down to the brook, wait while they drank, herd them back to the barn and time them up.  The task always took more time if they had to break a path through new and heavy snow.  Seems to me that one cow died as a result of falling into the icy water.

 




Orphan Pig Feed

 

Sometimes a piglet could not or would not suck from its mother.  A record book of Walter’s had the following recipe for “orphan pig feed.”

 

3 pints cow’s milk

2 eggs

¼ tsp salt

1-teaspoon cod liver oil

 

Keep dishes clean

title: CHURCH ORGANIZATIONS
summary: Documentation of organizations within St. Paul's Church structure, including missionary societies and youth groups.
content_preview:
CHURCH ORGANIZATIONS




Women’s Missionary Society




On June 11, 1926 a Presbyterian Women’s Missionary Society was formed with six members; the following officers were installed:




President – Mrs. John R. Godfrey

Vice President – Mrs. J. A. Watling

Secretary – Mrs. J. R. Cameron

Treasurer – Mrs. Robt. MacDougall




At the annual meeting held on June 6, 1927, the following highlights were reported:

12 meetings were held

10 new members were added

Average attendance was 11 members

Program activities included recitations, readings, study from “The Burning Bush”, and presentations by the Golden Hours Mission Band , and

Visitations from “Mrs. Williamson, Presbyterian Presbyterial President and several visitors from Chatham WMS and Bay due Vin auxiliary.”




The women’s Missionary Society is still active today.







Women’s League  




The Women’s League, meeting on Friday evenings as remembered by the writer, appeared to be a social and fund-raising body.  As I recall the Lleague held regular meetings, organized church suppers and catered for church events.







Mission Band

  

The Mission band was for the children of the church.  A reference in 1926 used the name Golden Hands Mission Band but at the church opening in 1930, it was referred to  s the Black River Mission Band.










Sunday School




The writer does not recall Sunday school anywhere but at the home of james and Kate Watling – in winter inside but in summer under the huge crab apple tree in the  back yard.




PYPS




A Presbyterian Young People’s Society was formed in 1930 with Venetia (Glendenning) Russell as the first President




In late 1930, discussions were held with Presbyterian congregations in both Kouchibouguac and Richibucto with a view to sharing the services of a full-time minister.  As a result, Knox Presbyterian Church, Kouchibouguac and St. Paul’s became a two-point charge.  In 1950, Calvin Presbyterian Church began to share a minister with St. Paul's and Knox –...

title: Differences in achievement between students is reflected by
summary: Brief note on tracking student achievement differences through range/nature of skills and performance levels. Proposes electronic record-keeping system showing learner progress with dated skill-level changes. Demonstrates Don's systems-thinking approach to education assessment and his focus on observable, measurable learning outcomes.
content_preview:
Differences in achievement between students is reflected by:

  
The range and nature of skills or competencies each person is able to perform.
  
Level of performance on each skill.   





I visualize the record keeping as a list of outcomes in a column down the left side of a page, although, it fact, the record will be generated electronically.  In the space to the right of each outcome, a teacher records and dates each change of level and such other information as may be germane to the learning process.  A glance at the page quickly shows the unfolding picture of a learner’s progress.  One can easily monitor by comparing current skills and levels with skills and levels at an earlier date. In term of monitoring and reporting progress, one literally “sees” growth happen.

About the author

title: Education bodies
summary: Glendenning analyzes organizational structures of Canadian education bodies (CAMET, CMEC) and provides critical comments on PEI education specifically. He identifies systemic problems: functions inadequately identified, major services not represented at organizational top levels, operations based on client institutions rather than service delivery, unclear roles and accountability, and confusion between "going to school" and "getting an education." He recommends restructuring based on functions, writing clear role descriptions, and delegating decision-making downward. He notes that OECD research shows better educational outcomes in schools with operational autonomy. This assessment likely drove his broader reform agenda.

title: Education Plan (2)
summary: Glendenning compares education plan priorities across Canadian provinces. New Brunswick emphasizes belonging, competencies, literacy, arts/science/trades, Indigenous education, and leadership development. Nova Scotia focuses on renewal, refocusing, rebuilding, and teamwork. Newfoundland/Labrador's 2018 plan addresses inclusive education, student health and welfare, mathematics, reading, Indigenous education, early years, and teacher development. PEI's priorities are marked with a question mark, suggesting Glendenning viewed PEI as lacking a coherent provincial education plan. This comparative analysis likely informed his reform recommendations for PEI.

title: Feeding pigs
summary: Don recalls the labor-intensive pig-feeding process: a dedicated shed near the house contained a large brick-based cooker (approximately 6 by 3 by 1.5 feet) where turnips and potatoes were boiled. The process involved cooking, mashing in 10-quart pails with meal, then carrying to the barn. Don vividly remembers the pungent aroma of cooking turnips and a painful childhood incident where he slipped on wet snow and rammed his arm into a hot pot of potatoes, leaving a burn mark visible for years.
content_preview:
Feeding the pigs




We always kept a few pigs at our place and it seems to me that we spent all of our time feeding them.  They often got a mixture of oats, barley and bran (just like seniors and their bran flakes). And of course either water or milk depending on the age of the pigs and any surplus milk.  In addition, a favourite at our place was either cooked potatoes or turnips.  




There was an old shed just outside our back door – probably 10 to 15 feet from the house.  It was not large – perhaps 8 by 12 feet and inside was a huge cooker.  I am not sure what the pot was made from but I think that it was probably 6 feet long and maybe three feet wide and 15 to 16 inches deep.  As a kid, it seemed very large to me.  It was set on a brick base so that a fire could be lighted under it.




Turnips were dumped into the tub, water was added, the turnips were cooked.  We likely cooked potatoes there as well abut I only remember the turnips.  Cooking took a lot wood, which was hauled, to the shed on a hand sled.  When finished, potatoes were put into a 10-quart pail, meal was added and the turnips were mashed by pushing a stick, a piece of stove wood from the woodpile, down into the pail.  When the turnips cooled, they were carried to the barn and emptied into the pig’s trough.  




Readers who eat turnip will know the strong aroma; imagine cooking large quantities several times a week in a building only used for that purpose.  By the way, the old cook shed was torn down in the early 1940’s when John built a garage for our 1939 Ford truck.




Sometimes potatoes were cooked on the kitchen stove for the same purpose.  A huge pot of potatoes would be boiled and the process would be repeated as with turnips.




At our house the kitchen stove was more or less at one end of the kitchen and the back door was reached through a little room at the other end.  I remember once, a pot of hot potatoes hot off the stove was sitting on the floor near the back door.  It was winter...

Covers learning models, curriculum, standards, assessments, professional development, school autonomy, and current challenges. Extensive references to educational research and international frameworks (OECD, World Bank). Reflects Don's lifelong commitment to educational theory and institutional development.

title: Fund 4 Technology
summary: Proposes a Youth Technology Camp intended to increase awareness of technology in use across Souris industries. The document provides demographic context on Souris: population 1,053 (declining 10% since 2011), median household income $42,368 (vs. PEI $61,163), with 28.6% residents over 65 and lower educational attainment than provincial average. Education 20/20 identified technology as a critical need through community consultations. The camp would provide 25 hours of instruction (five hours daily for five days in July 2018), with morning site visits and afternoon reporting/reflection. Objectives include community understanding, technology awareness, communication skills, and educational resource expansion. Demonstrates Don's data-informed approach and commitment to rural community development.

Souris

Souris
is a year-round port in Eastern PEI with a population of 1,053
(Statistics Canada, 2016 Census), a decline of 10% from the 2011
Census. Compared to PEI as a whole, Souris has a smaller proportion
of residents under age 15 (13.8% vs. 15.9%) and age 15 to 64 (57.6%
vs. 64.7%) and a higher proportion of residents age 65 and older
(28.6% vs. 19.4%). Souris also had a much lower median total
household income ($42,368) compared to PEI as a whole ($61,163).
Wealth generating activities are focused around tourism, farming,
marine services, fishing and related food processing, and the normal
trades and services of any small community. Compared to the PEI
population generally, Souris had a higher percentage of residents
with high school education only and a higher percentage without any
postsecondary educational certification as of the 2011 Census. Note:

title: Media following presentation
summary: Press release announcing results of Souris training needs study conducted by Education 20/20 with funding from SkillsPEI and the Canada-PEI Labour Market Agreement. The study examined training needs and employment barriers in this declining coastal community. Key findings: employers face shrinking labor pools and skill gaps, especially for specialized equipment; training institutions run at capacity; 40% of respondents had explored training in past three years; 59% prefer online instruction. Pressing needs identified include healthcare, small business, computer studies, and trades training. Study was conducted by MRSB (Maritime Regional School Board). The release emphasizes timeliness given PEI's growth and strong economy, requiring a flexible, skilled workforce. Demonstrates Don's ability to frame local community research in provincial economic context.

be revised after meeting

For immediate release








Opportunities and barriers:


Souris weighs in on training needs








Souris residents had an opportunity
Wednesday evening to hear first hand the results of a study about
training needs and opportunities in their community.  Like many other
small communities, Souris faces challenges of a declining population
and a seasonal workforce.   Employers are faced with a shrinking
labour pool and available people frequently lack needed skills,
especially skills needed to deal with specialized equipment. 









Training institutions in the area
are running at or near capacity and do not have the resources to
increase offerings; Holland College will be offering upgrading
classes including courses on line. Forty percent of respondents
reported exploring training opportunities in the past three years.
When asked about training need to improve their own employment
situation, respondents mentioned a wide range of practical courses in
the heath, small business, computer studies and trades such as
carpentry.  When asked their preferred delivery method, 59 percent
were interested in receiving instruction on line, 40% through night
school and 38% via correspondence or self study.








Strategies for closing the gap
include courses on line, more information about training options and
availability, hands on practical training, how to operate specialized
equipment, extending the school day at Souris High,

title: Media notes
summary: Media briefing notes announcing the training needs survey for adults in Souris, funded by SkillsPEI. The notes describe the study's three components: review of current offerings and capacity, assessment of resident and employer training needs, and community consultation. The study was positioned as addressing critical timing for PEI's economic growth, emphasizing the need for a flexible and skilled workforce. Education 20/20 Inc. is described as an independent, broad-based national charitable organization focused on quality education for all Canadians. The document represents Don's public communication strategy and his positioning of local community work within broader provincial economic narratives.
content_preview:
Souris Project

Media notes




Souris Study

We are pleased to announce a survey of needs for continuing education in the Souris area of PEI.  The study will include a survey and consultations with Souris residents together with a strategy for the future.  The study is being funded by SkillsPEI.




Training survey announced for Souris Area

Education 20/20 Inc. Is pleased to announce a training needs survey for adults in the Souris Area of Prince Edward island.  The study will include review of current offerings and capacity, interests and needs for further training as viewed by residents, employers and the community at large.  Residents will be invited to make their views known through the distribution of a questionnaire.  The study is being funded by SkillsPEI.




The study comes at a crucial time in that PEI is in the midst of population growth and a strong economy; future employment will require a flexible and skilled workforce. The final report will be made public include recommendations for decisionmakers as to future directions in adult education supports.




Education 20/20 Inc is an independent, broad-based national, charitable organization located in Prince Edward Island with a focus on ensuring a quality education for every Canadian.

title: Memorial Fund Generic Letter 2009 Mailout (1)
summary: Template letters (signed by John Robinson as President) thanking donors to the Community Foundation's Memorial Fund and Living Trust programs. Describes how funds support community beautification projects (planting Island oaks, memorial trees, gardens across PEI). Reflects Don's vision for community legacy-building and the philanthropic infrastructure he helped establish.
content_preview:
Letter to Donor to Memorial Fund 




Dear




On behalf of the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island, I want to thank you for your contribution(s) to the Memorial Fund and to let you know that your contributions have made a difference to the Island community.  




Memorial contributions are used to support the work of the Living Trust, a fund which enhances  public spaces throughout Prince Edward Island.  In 2007, for example, we planted a cluster of Island oaks on each side of the entrance to the Confederation Trail at Wood Islands.  In 2008, Memorial Funds were used to plant trees along the Confederation Trail at Milton, and we expect to add to the Milton site again this year.  Also this year, we will be planting a Memorial Tree at the Confederation Park in Charlottetown.  As funds allow, we will develop other sites throughout the Island and expand activities to include to include planting of gardens and shrubs and the placement of benches for the enjoyment of Islanders and visitors alike.




Should you be interested, you can now arrange memorials through our website.  Simply log on to our website at   HYPERLINK "http://www.cfpei.ca" www.cfpei.ca and follow the instructions of the Canada Helps icon.  You will receive your receipt immediately and we will send a suitable memorial card as directed by you.




Again, we  thank you for using our Memorial Fund.  As you will see from the enclosed brochure, our Living Trust also provides for memorial trees and sites.  We also administer family funds should you, or your friends or family, be interested.  




Your contribution to the work of the Community Foundation is appreciated.




Sincerely,




John Robinson

President

title: Newsletter 2021-1
summary: Don's newsletter from Glenway Estates community documenting spring activities, property maintenance, family updates, and community connections. References visits with Reid Lea and Brenda McInnis, Susanne Jones's cottage, and survey work. Shows Don's ongoing engagement with community property management and social connections.
content_preview:
GLENWAY ESTATES

Newsletter 2021-1




Greetings from Glenway Estates; in order to offset our age-gain, I decided to increase the font size a bit.

  
Trust all wintered well and looking forward to warmer weather. I’m planning my usual garden and looking forward to having ”friends  and neighbours “ back on the Point.
  
I visited our cottage at Glenway a few days ago and was able to drive all the way to the cottage; it was the driest “first spring drive” ever – no puddles. I drove the East side but probably could have driven out on the west side as well.  All the cottages looked welcoming but no sign of any inhabitants. Thanks< Paul, for your work on the road last year. While in the area, had a visit separately with both Reid Lea and Brenda McInnis.
  
As you probably know, some lots have been sold on Ronnie’s waterfront; one new cottage already erected; another lot has been purchased by Susanne Jones, who has family connections to Earnscliffe; I’ve known Susanne for many years first as a librarian at Holland College and later at UPEI.There may be a third lot but I’m not sure.
  
Spoke yesterday with Brian Potter; survey work has been done but new pin not yet in place. He will finish up and get back to me
  
Talked with Elizabeth yesterday; all are well. You will recall that our dues last year were in two parts - $100 plus $50.  Would appreciate your attention to the matter. if you have not already done so,  in preparation for some work on the property this year.
  
Looks as though the wind whipped around the sign on the gate post; I will purchase a new “Private” sign to replace it.
  
As you will recall, Paul secured a slightly used set of steps for the East Beach.  I’ll talk with Paul soon about having them installed.
  
Carol and I had both Covid shots and came through fine.





Best to all

Don

Glenway - 2021-1

Writing

The act of marking  a sequence of coherent letters, words, or symbols on paper and composing text to convey a meaningful message




Background

Range of material

Comprehension

Fluency

Independence

Speed

Vocabulary

GED includes word usage, mechanics, and organization)




Rating scale for writing




6	Creatively written while observing acceptable standards of grammar, sentence structure and organization. 

	5 	Very well organized showing precise and wide vocabulary, good sentence structure and appropriate grammar and some creativity. 

	4 	Organized with few errors in grammar and sentence structure. 

	3 	Organized with acceptable sentence structure, grammar and vocabulary. 

	Generally organized but uses limited vocabulary and has significant errors in grammar and sentence structure. 

1	Disorganized and unfocused with many errors in 

grammar and sentence structure accompanied by a 

limited vocabulary.

title: Notes 5 wriing
summary: Working notes on reading assessment and rating scales, outlining key performance criteria (range, comprehension, fluency, independence, speed, vocabulary) and proposing a 6-level proficiency scale applicable from high school through adult education. The framework reflects Don's systematic approach to defining measurable competencies independent of age or grade level.
content_preview:
Key Performance Criteria:

  
Range of material
  
Comprehension
  
Fluency
  
Independence
  
Speed
  
Vocabulary





Levels

Rating scales normally have at least a half dozen levels.  To complete a scale for reading, we need to add a brief description of other levels of reading ability, that is a way to describe readers  who read at higher or lower levels of proficiency.  While the above was created with high school graduation in mind, the same rating scale can be applied to adult readers at any level whether they be in college, university of adult classes.




Performance Levels (discernible):

  
6- Read a wide variety of printed materials with fluency and ease
  
5-
  
4-Read, without assistance, a range of printed materials with independence, fluency and ease
  
3- 
  
2-
  
1-
  
0- does not recognize any words on a printed page.

title: Oyster stew
summary: Regional oyster stew recipe featuring fresh shucked oysters, milk, butter, and Worcestershire sauce, with salt and pepper to taste. Preparation involves heating oysters until curled, warming milk with seasonings separately, then combining without boiling. Yields three servings and served with crackers. Recipe reflects Atlantic Canadian coastal culinary traditions and seafood preparation methods.
content_preview:
OYSTER STEW







Ingredients

250 ml shucked  oysters

500 ml 10% milk

Salt – ½ tsp

Butter – size of an egg

Pepper – ½ tsp

Worcestershire sauce – ½ tsp




Procedure

Heat oysters in fry pan until oysters begin to curl

Add salt, butter, pepper to milk and heat in separate sauce pan

Combine, do not boil

add Worcestershire sauce to suit taste




Serve with crackers

Makes three servings

title: Standardized testing
summary: (145 words):** Don separates testing purposes: diagnostic testing helps teachers improve instruction, while institutional sorting contradicts educational goals. He argues that sorting students should cease entirely since most learners can achieve high levels given adequate time and support. Don supports standardized testing for system-level planning—helping administrators understand resource needs and identify systemic weaknesses requiring attention. However, he strongly objects to using individual results for ranking. Don frames test scores as personal information, comparable to medical records, accessible only to directly involved parties. He advocates a complete redesign of testing culture to prioritize student achievement over ranking, supporting individual teacher testing while opposing institutional sorting mechanisms.
content_preview:
25 STANDARDIZED TESTING




The debate on standardized testing is endless without any agreement in sight or any middle ground. Given the heat, if not light, cast by the debate, it may be time to step back and ask a few basic questions. 




“Why test?”  A teacher tests for two reasons – to diagnose or determine a learner’s current level as a basis for developing a teaching strategy.   Later a teacher tests to see if the strategy worked.  All tests, like all learning are individual although often undertaken by a student in a group setting.   Test results are for the information and benefit of the teacher, student and parents.  Test results constitute personal information, just as personal as the results of medical tests.    




Schools also test to sort or rank students although I’m not really sure why schools take on this responsibility.  In my view, sorting has nothing to do with education and has no place in schools. A teacher’s focus should be on helping a learner reach the desired level of achievement.  All, or practically all, who enter are capable of reaching high levels of achievement.  If it takes one learner a few days longer than another to complete the program, so what?  The important thing is that students reach the desired level of performance.    




And what of standardized tests?  People who plan and provide and pay for learning resources, the Minister and the bureaucracy, need information about actual and likely users of the education system so that they can make available learning resources and opportunities of the right kind and in the right mix.  Planners need to know the nature of learning assistance required, numbers requiring each kind of assistance, otherwise they cannot plan properly.  They likely also need to know specifics about reading levels, vocabulary, literacy, numeracy, etc.   Results may indicate some areas requiring attention or extra resources.  They may show weaknesses in some schools at certain levels within the system.  While...

title: Waste Watch
summary: Detailed instructions on sorting garbage, compost, and recyclables for the Island Waste Watch Commission. Specifies green carts for compostible materials, black carts for non-recyclables, blue bags for newspapers and cans. Demonstrates Don's attention to detail in preparing guides for exchange guests and awareness of environmental responsibility.
content_preview:
ISLAND WASTE WATCH COMMISSION

Telephone: 1-888—280-8111




SORTING OF GARBAGE







All wet or dry compostible garbage, foodstuffs, soiled paper, cardboard, plant material etc. in green cart. Place a small compostable clear mini-bag in small green container on counter for wet garbage and drop bags into green cart as necessary.

Garbage may be wrapped in newspapers and dropped into green cart.

Saran wrap, aluminum foil, plastic wrap or anything that is not compostibles placed in black cart.

Newspapers are placed in blue bag

 Bottles and cans are rinsed and placed in a different blue bag provided in the garage

 Everything else goes in the waste cart (black) which is on alternate Tuesdays from the green cart. Example razor blades, non-recyclable plastics, soiled foam meat or fish packaging, saran wrap etc.
